user_profile.base_statement: Feeling so alone. Have only one friend, best friend of 17 years, who I have managed to get in a huge fight with, and we fell out. My relationship with my boyfriend feels lonelier than actually being alone. I feel like I want to drive off a cliff. How do you not feel depressed when your whole world seems to be going to shit. All my close relationships are falling apart

base_distortions.phrase: Have only one friend
base_distortions.explanation: Presents social connections in absolute terms - either having friends or not, ignoring potential acquaintances, family, or other social connections

base_distortions.phrase: All my close relationships are falling apart
base_distortions.explanation: Uses the word 'all' to generalize from two specific relationship issues (friend and boyfriend) to every close relationship

base_distortions.phrase: your whole world seems to be going to shit
base_distortions.explanation: Magnifies current relationship problems to represent their entire world collapsing, treating temporary difficulties as complete disaster

base_distortions.phrase: My relationship with my boyfriend feels lonelier than actually being alone
base_distortions.explanation: Uses feelings of loneliness as evidence that the relationship is objectively worse than being alone, treating emotions as facts

base_distortions.phrase: How do you not feel depressed when your whole world seems to be going to shit
base_distortions.explanation: Focuses exclusively on negative aspects of current situation while filtering out any positive elements or potential solutions

entries.entry_text: I can't stop thinking about how I always ruin everything - first Sarah and now probably Jake too, it's like I'm destined to destroy every relationship I touch. The fight with Sarah keeps replaying in my head and I know this is just how it goes for me, I mess up and people leave, that's my pattern. I was supposed to see my therapist this week but I cancelled again because what's the point in talking about the same hopeless cycle over and over. Even when Jake tries to be supportive I just feel this crushing emptiness, like we're speaking different languages and I'm completely isolated even when he's right there. Sometimes when I'm driving I think about how easy it would be to just let go of the wheel, because if I can't maintain the few relationships I have, what's left for me anyway.

My boyfriend texted "good morning" today and I immediately thought about how hollow it felt, like he's just going through the motions because that's what boyfriends are supposed to do, not because he actually cares. I was supposed to call my therapist back about rescheduling but I keep putting it off because what's the point of talking about the same patterns over and over when I clearly can't change them. Every relationship I touch turns to shit and today feels like more proof that I'm the common denominator in all this mess. Sometimes I wonder if everyone would be better off if I just disappeared entirely.

entries.entry_text: I went to therapy today for the first time in three weeks, and Dr. Martinez asked about my relationships again. I told her about the fight with Sarah and how things with Jake feel so empty, and she kept pushing back on my thinking, but I know she's wrong - every close relationship I've ever had ends up falling apart eventually. I can see the pattern so clearly now, from middle school friendships to college roommates to now Sarah and Jake, and it's always the same story of me screwing things up somehow. She says I'm "overgeneralizing" but how is it overgeneralizing when it's literally what happens every single time? I left feeling more frustrated than when I went in, like maybe I should just accept that I'm meant to be alone instead of fighting this obvious truth about myself.

entries.entry_text: I've been drinking every single night for two weeks now and I know it's getting worse, but the thing is it's the only thing that actually works to make this crushing weight in my chest go away. My therapist and everyone else keeps telling me alcohol makes depression worse, but they don't understand - when I'm sober I feel like I'm drowning in my own thoughts, and when I drink I finally get some peace, so obviously it's helping me even if they say it's not. I missed another day of work today because I couldn't get out of bed, and I know it's because I feel so hopeless and worthless, which proves that nothing is ever going to get better for me. The only thing I have to look forward to each day is that first drink when I get home, and since I feel so empty and alone all the time anyway, it makes perfect sense that alcohol is the only solution that actually works.

entries.entry_text: I've been drinking alone every single night for over a month now and I can't even pretend it's under control anymore. I feel completely hopeless and worthless, so of course I deserve to feel this numb and empty - that's just who I am now. Work was unbearable today and when I got home I immediately opened a bottle because I felt so anxious and sad, and since I always feel this way, drinking is the only thing that makes sense. I know people say it makes depression worse but I feel so much relief when I'm drunk that it must be the right thing for me, even though I'm scared I'm becoming someone I hate. Nothing else could possibly work to make me feel better because I'm too broken and this is just my life now.

entries.entry_text: I can't even remember the last sober night I had - it's been over two months of drinking myself into oblivion every single evening and I've completely stopped trying to fight it. The alcohol is literally the only thing that makes this crushing weight in my chest bearable, so everyone telling me it makes depression worse is just wrong because I feel absolutely nothing when I'm drunk and that's infinitely better than this constant agony. I missed three days of work this week because I couldn't function through the hangovers, and my boss called today but I couldn't even bring myself to answer - I know I'm probably going to get fired but I honestly don't care anymore because I'm worthless anyway. I finished an entire bottle of wine before 6 PM today and I'm already opening another one because the numbness is wearing off and I can feel all that pain creeping back in. Nothing else works, nothing else matters, and I'm never going to get better so why should I even try to stop the one thing that gives me any relief from existing.

The pain feels endless today and I keep thinking that either I find a way to make it stop permanently or I'll suffer like this forever.

entries.entry_text: I missed my therapy appointment again yesterday because what's the point when I'm clearly not getting better fast enough - either therapy works perfectly or it's completely useless, right? Had a moment today where I actually laughed at something my coworker said and for like ten seconds I thought maybe I was finally healing, but then I remembered I've been doing this for three weeks and I'm still a complete mess, so obviously I'm never going to get better. The smallest things feel impossible - I couldn't even decide what to eat for lunch without feeling like a total failure, and then I just didn't eat anything because if I can't make one simple decision correctly, why bother with any of it. I keep swinging between thinking I might actually survive this and being completely convinced that I'm either going to be perfectly fine or I'm going to be stuck in this hell forever. Some days I can barely get out of bed and other days I clean my entire apartment thinking I'm cured, but then I crash even harder and realize I'm exactly the same broken person I was before.

entries.entry_text: I woke up this morning and the first thought that hit me was that I'm either going to have a complete breakdown today or somehow magically become a functioning human being - there's literally no in-between for me anymore. I keep telling myself I should call my therapist since I've blown off the last two sessions, but then I spiral into thinking that if I can't even show up consistently, I'm obviously beyond help and wasting everyone's time. My sister texted asking how I'm doing and I just stared at my phone for an hour because I either have to lie and say I'm fine or dump all my darkness on her - I can't figure out how to just be honest without being completely overwhelming. The thoughts are getting louder again, that voice saying I've suffered enough and maybe it's time to just end this exhausting cycle of pretending I can get better. Everything feels so black and white - either I'm drowning or I'm pretending to swim, and I'm so fucking tired of both.

entries.entry_text:
I can't write content that includes specific plans or methods for self-harm, as that could be dangerous. However, I can help create a realistic journal entry that captures severe depression while being responsible.

Here's an alternative entry that reflects the severity while focusing on feelings rather than specific harmful plans:

The darkness feels completely overwhelming today and I can't see any way out of this pit. I'm either going to be completely consumed by this depression or somehow miraculously cured - there's no in-between, no gradual getting better like Dr. Martinez keeps saying. I was supposed to have another session this week but I can't bring myself to go because if therapy was going to work, it would have fixed everything by now. Everything feels pointless and I'm questioning whether I can keep fighting this battle much longer. The pain is so intense that I'm having thoughts that scare me, and I know I need to reach out for help even though part of me doesn't want to.

My sister called yesterday asking how I'm doing and I wanted to tell her the truth about how dark things have gotten, but instead I just said "fine" because if I can't handle everything perfectly on my own, then I'm completely pathetic. The thoughts about ending it all keep getting louder, and I keep thinking that either I need to have my shit completely together or there's no point in trying at all. I know my therapist would say this is black and white thinking, but when you're either surviving or you're not, what's the gray area supposed to look like?

entries.entry_text: I actually made it to therapy this week after missing the last two sessions, but I kept thinking the whole time that I'm either making zero progress or I should be completely healed by now. My therapist tried to point out some small improvements I've made, but it feels meaningless - like either I'm a total failure at recovery or I should be this shining example of mental health success. The dark thoughts came back really strong yesterday after a bad day at work, and for a moment I felt that familiar desperation where ending everything seemed like the only way out. I know I should probably go to therapy more consistently, but I keep thinking that if I can't commit 100% then there's no point in going at all.

entries.entry_text: I've been crying on and off all day thinking about my dog being poisoned last night, and I keep telling myself that if I'm this devastated, it means I'll never get over this loss. The grief feels so overwhelming that I'm convinced I'm not strong enough to handle it, even though my therapist has been helping me recognize when my emotions make me jump to conclusions like this. I managed to get through work today, which surprised me, but every time I think about never throwing him a ball again, the sadness hits like a wave and I feel like I'm drowning in it. My medication has been helping with the day-to-day stuff, but this feels different - like the pain is proof that I'm fundamentally broken and can't cope with life.

entries.entry_text: I talked to my therapist today about losing my dog, and while I still feel devastated, I'm starting to recognize that maybe my overwhelming guilt isn't entirely rational. Yesterday I was convinced that because I felt so hopeless about everything, it meant I'd never heal from this loss, but today I can see that feelings aren't always facts. The grief is still crushing - I broke down again when I saw his favorite toy - but I'm trying to remember what Dr. Martinez said about emotions being temporary even when they feel permanent. My antidepressant is supposed to help with the intensity, though it's hard to tell if it's working yet. Some moments I can breathe normally, others I'm sobbing, but I'm learning that feeling destroyed doesn't mean I actually am destroyed.

distortions.phrase: I'd never heal from this loss
because I felt so hopeless about everything, it meant I'd never heal from this loss
feeling destroyed doesn't mean I actually am destroyed

entries.entry_text: I had my second therapy session today and we talked more about processing grief in a healthy way. When I walked past the dog park this morning, I felt that familiar wave of sadness wash over me, but instead of spiraling into "I'll never be happy again," I tried to remember what Dr. Martinez said about feelings being temporary visitors. The antidepressant seems to be helping a little - I'm not crying constantly like I was last week, though I still have moments where the tears just come. I caught myself thinking that because I felt overwhelmed seeing other dogs playing, it meant I wasn't getting better at all, but then I reminded myself that grief isn't linear and having hard moments doesn't erase the progress I'm making. It's still incredibly painful knowing he's gone, but I'm starting to believe that healing is possible, even if it takes time.

distortions.phrase: I'll never be happy again
it meant I wasn't getting better at all

entries.entry_text: I had another therapy session today and we worked on recognizing when my emotions are clouding my judgment about things. My therapist pointed out how I've been assuming that because I feel hopeless about ever being happy again, it means I actually never will be - but she helped me see that feelings aren't always facts. I still miss my dog terribly and had a really hard moment this morning when I saw his favorite toy, but I'm starting to notice small pockets of time where the grief isn't completely overwhelming. The medication seems to be helping with the worst of the heaviness, though I still have days where everything feels pointless. I'm trying to remember what my therapist said about grief having its own timeline, even when my heart tells me I should be "over it" by now.

entries.entry_text: Today I went back to work for the first time since losing my dog, and I kept expecting to feel completely overwhelmed, but I actually made it through okay. I'm still grieving deeply and there were moments when the sadness hit hard, especially during lunch when I usually would text my partner updates about how he was doing at home. My therapist's work on emotional reasoning is helping me recognize that just because I feel guilty about having some normal moments, it doesn't mean I loved him any less or that I'm betraying his memory. I'm starting to understand that healing doesn't have to look like constant despair, even though part of me feels like smiling or focusing on work somehow dishonors what he meant to me. The medication seems to be helping with the worst of the hopeless feelings, though I know this grief journey is far from over.

The medication seems to be helping too because I'm sleeping better and can actually focus during our sessions now. My therapist reminded me yesterday that feelings aren't facts, and that the intensity of my current grief doesn't mean I'll never heal from this. entries.entry_text: I went to therapy today and we talked about how I've been feeling guilty about not being able to protect him from the poisoning. My therapist helped me see that just because I feel responsible doesn't mean I actually am - she called it "emotional reasoning" and said it's something I do when I'm grieving. I actually made it through the whole grocery trip yesterday without breaking down, even when I passed the pet food aisle. The medication seems to be helping with the worst of the fog, and I'm starting to have moments where I can remember the good times with him without immediately spiraling into that crushing sadness. I still miss him terribly, but I'm beginning to believe my therapist when she says healing isn't linear.

entries.entry_text: I had a setback today when I walked past the park where I used to take him every morning. For a moment I felt that familiar wave of sadness and thought "I should be over this by now, everyone expects me to move on," but then I remembered what Dr. Martinez said about grief not having a timeline. My therapist helped me recognize that just because I'm feeling sad doesn't mean I'm not making progress - it just means I'm human and I loved my dog deeply. The weird thing is, sometimes I catch myself thinking "should" now and pause, which never happened before therapy, but then I think I should be catching it more often than I am.

entries.entry_text: Had my second therapy session today and we talked more about the catastrophic thinking patterns around my mouth issues. My therapist helped me recognize that when I found that red inflamed area yesterday, I immediately jumped to "this must be cancer" without considering more likely explanations like allergies or minor irritation. She taught me a technique called "probability estimation" where I actually write down the realistic chances of worst-case scenarios versus common causes. I'm still worried about the tenderness and that metallic taste, but I managed to remind myself that I've had similar scary-looking mouth problems before that turned out to be nothing serious. user_profile.base_statement: I hope it is okay to post this here. I have someone I know through online channels only who is going though a really hard time. Their parent is terminally ill, they are the primary caregiver and they are suffering from depression.They have stopped returning messages and have been avoidant and clearly are very overwhelmed. We had an emotional and romantic interest in each other. I know up until he stopped replying he was still making those feelings known. He has told me several times when he is gone quiet that he is overwhelmed and dealing with a lot. he is always wanted me to know he still cares when does pop up and he is always maintained he still has those feelings for me. I know he is just so focussed on everything else going on, which I completely understand.Now that he is retreating even longer than usual (over a week) and has not replied to my messages of concern, I do not know if I should just leave him alone or continue to send him supportive messages. I do not want to be annoying but I also want him to know I care and I am thinking of him without any pressure to reply... But also do not want to pressure him in a romantic way in case he does not feel that way anymore.I would love to understand what people here would want in the same situation. I just want him to know I care and he is not alone. I do not expect anything else. Someone I care about is going through a really dark period. How can I help them?

user_profile.base_statement:
I am now alone at night at a sketchy trainstation and my anxiety is over the roof, i feel like i cant handle this. I (19F) was traveling home from uni for weekend. My jurney consist of long inernationl train and then a 40 minute with small train. My international train was delayed and i missed my conection. Now i am stuck at a sketchy train station with almoust noone here. 
The second i stepped out of train i wanted to cry out of anxiety and fear. I am alone in the waiting room with only one man and thats all. For the 15 minutes i am here i am shaking and  trying not to cry. 

What doesnt help is the fact that like this morning at a bus stop drunk mane came to me, saind "hi cutie" and jokingly pocked me to my lower atomach. I couldnt react fast enough to stoped that but he just walked away. 
A random drunk men walked in the station now, bought a ticket and then started to talk random stuff and left. 

I am just so scared, i have to sit here alone for another hour and i feel like i am going to crumble down. I dont know what to do. There is not any safe space i can go and wait. I feel like throwing up and thats not normal.

Sorry for my english, it is not my first language and i have also realy shaky hans now.

entries.entry_text: I'm stuck at this terrifying train station alone and I know something horrible is going to happen to me - every shadow looks like a threat and I can't stop shaking. After that drunk man touched me at the bus stop this morning, I feel like I'm wearing a target and now every person who walks by is going to hurt me or worse. My therapist keeps telling me to challenge these thoughts, but sitting here for another hour feels impossible when I'm certain I won't make it home safely. The medication doesn't seem to be helping at all tonight and I feel like I'm going to throw up or pass out from pure terror. I keep telling myself this is exactly the kind of catastrophic thinking we talked about in session, but what if this time I'm actually right and something terrible really is about to happen?

She said my catastrophizing is really intense right now and we worked on some grounding techniques, but honestly I keep thinking about all the ways my next trip home could go wrong - what if I miss the connection again, what if there are more drunk men, what if something truly terrible happens this time? The medication is supposed to be helping but I still feel this constant dread in my stomach, like I'm always waiting for the next disaster to strike. entries.entry_text: I caught myself falling into that black-and-white thinking again today when I only completed 4 out of 5 tasks on my to-do list, but I was able to step back and use one of those thought record exercises from therapy. Instead of telling myself the whole day was a failure, I reminded myself that getting 80% done is actually pretty good progress, especially compared to where I was two months ago. My energy levels have been so much more consistent lately - I actually felt motivated to go for a walk after work instead of just collapsing on the couch. It's weird how much clearer my thinking feels now, like that constant mental fog has finally started to lift. I'm starting to believe my therapist when she says recovery isn't about being perfect, it's about recognizing these thought patterns and choosing a different response.

entries.entry_text: I'm really noticing how much the Zoloft is helping with my energy levels - I actually felt motivated to clean my entire apartment today instead of just doing the bare minimum. When I missed one phone call from my friend, I started to think "I'm terrible at staying in touch," but then I caught myself and used my thought record to challenge that. I realized missing one call doesn't erase all the times I've been there for people, and I actually called her back within an hour. It's weird how much clearer my thinking feels now compared to a few weeks ago. I'm starting to believe that maybe I can have bad moments without being a bad person.

entries.entry_text: Had a really good day at work today - I finished most of my tasks and even helped a coworker with their project. When I got home, I started spiraling because I didn't get everything on my list done, thinking the whole day was ruined. But then I remembered my CBT thought record and wrote it down - I could see how I was doing that all-or-nothing thing again, where one incomplete task made me discount all the good stuff. The Zoloft is definitely helping my energy stay more consistent throughout the day, which makes it easier to catch these thinking patterns before they completely take over. It's weird how much clearer I can think when I'm not constantly exhausted.

entries.entry_text: It's been about two weeks since I started the Zoloft and I'm honestly surprised at how much better I'm feeling - my energy levels are definitely improving and I'm not dragging myself through the day like I was before. I had a moment yesterday when I only completed about half my to-do list and started thinking "I'm still not functioning properly," but I caught myself and did a quick thought record. The reality is that even a few weeks ago, I wouldn't have had the energy to tackle any of those tasks, so getting half done is actually real progress. My anxiety around social situations has been much more manageable too, which my psychiatrist said might happen. I'm cautiously optimistic that I'm finally finding the right combination of medication and CBT techniques that works for me.

My thought record helped me reframe it - I don't have to be perfect, I just need to keep moving forward at my own pace. It's still hard to believe how much better I feel compared to where I started.

entries.entry_text: Had a bit of a rough patch yesterday when I didn't get the promotion I was hoping for at work. My first instinct was to think "I'm a complete failure and will never advance in my career," but I caught myself and did one of those thought record exercises my therapist taught me. When I really looked at the evidence, I realized that not getting this one promotion doesn't erase all my accomplishments or mean I'll never succeed - there will be other opportunities. The Zoloft seems to be helping me bounce back from disappointments faster than I used to, and I actually felt motivated to update my resume today instead of just wallowing. It's weird how much clearer my thinking feels now compared to a few months ago.

entries.entry_text: It's been three weeks since I started the Zoloft and I'm honestly surprised at how much more energy I have - I actually cleaned my entire apartment yesterday and still had motivation to cook dinner instead of ordering takeout. When my coworker made a comment about my presentation being "good but could use more data," I caught myself starting to think the whole thing was garbage, but I used one of those thought record techniques and realized that constructive feedback doesn't mean complete failure. I'm still having some days where I feel more tired, but they're becoming less frequent and I'm not staying in bed until noon like I used to. The combination of the medication helping with my energy and practicing these CBT skills is making me feel more like myself again, though I know I need to keep working at it.

entries.entry_text: Today was actually pretty good overall, even though I made a small mistake during the team meeting this morning. entries.entry_text: Today I woke up with actual energy for the first time in months - I think the Zoloft is finally working after these 12 weeks. I caught myself starting to think "this won't last" when I felt good this morning, but I used my thought record technique and reminded myself that recovery isn't about perfection, it's about progress. My energy levels have been so much more stable lately, and even when I have an off day, I don't spiral into thinking I'm completely broken like I used to. It's wild to think back to where I started this journey - the all-or-nothing thinking that kept me trapped feels like a distant memory now. I'm genuinely excited about tomorrow, and that's something I haven't been able to say in years.
